paragraphs:
[1]
Simpson, J.
: The applicant is a Jewish citizen of Moldova, and he is Russian speaking. The Board accepted his evidence and concluded that he suffered discrimination at his job and in his job search efforts. It also concluded that he suffered harassment and one beating by reason of his Jewish heritage. The Board, however, did not find that the applicant had an objectively well-founded fear of persecution. It found instead that he was a victim of discrimination.

[2]
The issue raised by the applicant is whether the Board ought to have commented on certain documents in addition to those mentioned in the reasons. As a starting point in my analysis, I should note that the Board cannot comment on all documents in its record, and the fact that no mention is made of a document does not necessarily mean that the document has been ignored. It is reasonable to presume that the Board will consider all important documents.

[3]
However, the question is when is a document so important that it must be specifically mentioned in the decision. Or put another way, when will a failure to refer to a document be considered a reviewable error?

[4]
In my view, a document need only be mentioned in a decision if, first of all, the document is timely, in the sense that it bears on the relevant time period. Secondly, it must be prepared by a reputable, independent author who is in a position to be the most reliable source of information. Thirdly, it seems to me that the topic addressed in the document must be directly relevant to an applicant's claim. For example, documents sent to or received by an applicant, or prepared for an applicant, or about an applicant, which bear on relevant issues would, in the ordinary course be mentioned in reasons. In addition, if a document is directly relevant to the facts alleged by an applicant, one would expect to see that document addressed in the Board's reasons. On the other hand, numerous other documents may be only marginally relevant. In my view, it is not a reviewable error for the Board to fail to deal with such documents in its reasons.

[5]
In this case, the Board did not refer to two items. The first was a document which was marked as Exhibit C-4. It was a commentary written by a Mr. Alex Benifand on a report which appears to have been prepared for the IRB. It related to, among other things, the circumstances experienced by the Jewish community in Moldova. In his commentary, Mr. Benifand disagreed with certain findings in the IRB report. He did not appear to reject the report as a whole, but mentioned that he had a concern that hate propaganda continued to exist in Moldova, and that it created serious stress on members of the Jewish community. He also mentioned that there have been serious anti-Semitic incidents in Moldova, such as burglary and defacing of cemeteries, and in one case at least, a murder. He mentioned that Jews were often the first to be laid off during corporate lay-offs.

[6]
Mr. Benifand's commentary was not mentioned in the Board's decision. Instead, the Board relied on documents which provided information from members of the Jewish community in Moldova about the situation there. One of the authors was the President of the Federation of Jewish Communities, who said that there was no anti-Semitism in respect of either state policy or social phenomena. The Board also quoted from the IRB study that was criticized by Mr. Benifand. That study said that state financing in Moldova had been provided for the Department of Jewish Studies at the university, and that Jewish synagogues and cultural groups were reopening in Moldova.

[7]
The Board did not expressly reject Mr. Benifand's comments, and that is the source of the difficulty. The Board failed to address his commentary in positive or negative terms. In my view, an express reference was unnecessary for two reasons. Firstly, Mr. Benifand's concerns for the most part did not mirror those raised by the applicant. The applicant was not concerned about hate propaganda and did not say that he had been the victim of vandalism or burglary, or incidents of that kind. Secondly, Mr. Benifand's comments were less authoritative than those from members of the Jewish community in Moldova. Accordingly, I find that there was no reviewable error in the Board's failure to specifically address Mr. Benifand's commentary.

[8]
In addition, there were other documents which dealt generally with discrimination against ethnic minorities in Moldova, to which the Board did not make specific reference. Those documents did not specifically address the Jewish situation. Accordingly, the Board's failure to mention them does not constitute a reviewable error.

[9]
The application is therefore dismissed.
Application dismissed.
Editor: Jana A. Andersen/nmg
[End of document]

legal_issues: The extent of an administrative body's obligation to explicitly address all submitted evidence in its decision-making process.
The criteria for determining when a failure to reference specific evidence constitutes a reviewable error.
The relevance of evidence source credibility in administrative decision-making.
The standard for evaluating the materiality of evidence in relation to an applicant's claims.
The permissible scope of reliance on differing sources of information when assessing factual claims.
factual_background: The applicant is a Jewish citizen of Moldova who speaks Russian.
The applicant reported experiencing discrimination in employment and job searching.
The applicant reported experiencing harassment and a physical assault due to his Jewish heritage.
The Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) accepted evidence of discrimination and harassment but did not find an objectively well-founded fear of persecution.
A commentary (Exhibit C-4) by Alex Benifand on an IRB report regarding the Jewish community in Moldova was not addressed in the IRB’s decision.
Benifand’s commentary expressed concern about ongoing hate propaganda and anti-Semitic incidents (burglary, cemetery defacement, murder) in Moldova, and discriminatory employment practices.
The IRB relied on a report from the President of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Moldova, who stated there was no anti-Semitism, and on the IRB study criticized by Benifand.
Other documents addressing discrimination against ethnic minorities in Moldova, but not specifically the Jewish situation, were also not specifically referenced by the IRB.

Applicants: The Board ought to have commented on Exhibit C-4, a commentary by Alex Benifand, which disagreed with certain findings in an IRB report regarding the situation of the Jewish community in Moldova.

Benifand’s commentary highlighted the continued existence of hate propaganda, serious anti-Semitic incidents (burglary, cemetery defacing, murder), and discriminatory layoff practices against Jews in Moldova.
The Board’s failure to address Benifand’s commentary, either positively or negatively, constituted a reviewable error.
Respondents: The Board was not required to comment on all documents in the record; failure to mention a document does not necessarily mean it was ignored.
A document need only be mentioned if it is timely, prepared by a reputable and independent author, and directly relevant to the applicant’s claim.
Benifand’s concerns did not mirror those raised by the applicant (who did not allege hate propaganda, vandalism, burglary, or similar incidents).
Benifand’s commentary was less authoritative than information provided by members of the Jewish community in Moldova, including the President of the Federation of Jewish Communities.
Other documents dealing generally with discrimination against ethnic minorities in Moldova were not specifically relevant to the Jewish situation and therefore did not require comment.

court_analysis: The central issue was whether the Board erred by not specifically addressing certain documents submitted by the applicant. The court clarified that a Board is not required to comment on every document, and silence doesn't automatically equate to disregard.

The court established a three-part test for determining when a failure to mention a document constitutes a reviewable error: the document must be timely, prepared by a reputable and independent author in a position to provide reliable information, and directly relevant to the applicant’s claim.

The court found that Exhibit C-4, a commentary by Mr. Benifand, met the first two parts of the test (timeliness and author reputability) but not the third. While Benifand’s concerns about anti-Semitism in Moldova were noted, they didn’t align with the applicant’s specific claims of discrimination and harassment.

The court reasoned that the Board’s reliance on statements from the President of the Federation of Jewish Communities and the IRB study (which Benifand criticized) was justifiable, as these sources were deemed more authoritative and directly related to the broader context of the applicant’s claim.

The court emphasized that the Board didn’t explicitly reject Benifand’s comments, but an express reference wasn’t necessary because his concerns were largely distinct from the applicant’s experience and his commentary was less authoritative than other evidence considered.

The court also determined that the Board’s failure to mention other documents dealing generally with ethnic minority discrimination in Moldova was not an error, as those documents didn’t specifically address the Jewish situation and were therefore only marginally relevant.
